fact: Founded in 1851, the paper has won 125 Pulitzer Prizes, more than any other newspaper.
The Times is ranked 17th in the world by circulation and 2nd in the U.S.
Nicknamed "The Gray Lady", the Times has long been regarded within the industry as a national "newspaper of record".
The main office of The New York Times was attacked during the New York City Draft Riots.
The newspaper's influence grew in 1870 and 1871, when it published a series of exposés on William Tweed, leader of the city's Democratic Party—popularly known as "Tammany Hall".
In the 1880s, The New York Times gradually transitioned from supporting Republican Party candidates in its editorials to becoming more politically independent and analytical.
In the 1970s, the paper introduced a number of new lifestyle sections including Weekend and Home, with the aim of attracting more advertisers and readers.
The New York Times switched to a digital production process sometime before 1980, but only began preserving the resulting digital text that year.
The newspaper moved its headquarters to the Times Tower, located at 1475 Broadway in 1904.
Since 1896, the newspaper's slogan has been "All the News That's Fit to Print.".
